awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type II:  The University of Akron I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project from the University of Akron to extend and expand their existing I-Corps Site. Akron was one of the first three Sites funded through the I-Corps program. NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. This project represents a Type II Site. There are two types of I-Corps Site proposals: Type I proposals are submitted by institutions that have not had prior funding as an I-Corps Site;Type II proposals are submitted by institutions that have had prior funding as an I-Corps Site

This is a strong project based on a history of success and a demonstrated commitment to the I-Corps process. UA is achieving their goals of preparing teams for the National program and/or I-Corps@Ohio; encouraging collaboration and enhancing understanding of innovation and entrepreneurship as evidenced by the number of teams that are completing the Site program; continuing on with additional training and receiving external funding. There is evidence of a strong network of support from the university and community as well as an experienced leadership team and mentor network. UA has a very strong track record of translating innovative ideas into companies, and the system created I-Corps@Ohio, a statewide I-Corps program. Under-represented participants are encouraged through the Jumpstart inclusion program and the UA Site has been particularly successful in including women in their programs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Project Outcomes Report should serve as a brief summary (200-800 words), prepared specifically for the public, of the nature and outcomes of the project. The report should describe the project outcomes or findings that address the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the work as defined in the NSF merit review criteria.

 

Under this National Science Foundation (NSF) I-Corps Site award, The University of Akron (UAkron) ran 23 I-Corps cohorts through which it trained 118 NSF funded teams, including 113 faculty, 182 students, and 111 mentors. Teams came from 20 UAkron departments and five UAkron colleges, along with programs of excellence at Bowling Green State University, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland State University, Kent State University, Lorain County Community College, Miami University, Northeast Ohio Medical University, Oberlin College, Ohio Northern University, UAkron, University of Cincinnati, University of Dayton, University of Mount Union, and University of Toledo. Each team has received basic training in customer discovery and business model canvas hypotheses, and has received detailed feedback from I-Corps administrators.

 

UAkron?s I-Corps Site has also opened up to non-university teams, including those that are not based on NSF research but still have a differentiated business model. These teams are incorporated into the cohorts alongside more technical university teams, which enhances the experience for all involved by increasing diversity, sparking creative collaborations, and forcing teams to explain their ideas in less technical ways. Non-university teams are funded by a private foundation and included 131 teams with 197 students and entrepreneurial leads, and 138 mentors during the grant period.

 

All participating teams attend 11 hours of in-person meetings, during which they learn about the basics of the business model canvas, customer interview methodology, product-market fit, determining market size, competitive analysis, customer archetypes, work flow maps, and follow-on funding opportunities. Entrepreneurial Leads give weekly lessons learned presentations with real-time flipped classroom feedback. Each team meets one-on-one with the instructors during office hours sessions and benefits from having an outside business mentor to guide their team throughout the process.

 

88 companies have been formed by I-Corps graduate teams during the period of the I-Corps renewal grant in addition to 25 startups formed by I-Corps teams during the original grant. Recent I-Corps Site graduates have been accepted to prestigious accelerator programs like Y Combinator and TechStars. UAkron I-Corps graduates have also received 22 SBIR/STTR awards, totaling more than $6.5 million in federal funding.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2022
Modified by: Philip A Allen
